challenge.impact: Reduces the long-term energy storage capability of lithium-ion batteries, limiting their practical application.

solution.description: Doping with 2% Cr improved cycle performance by ∼13%.
solution.methodology: Cationic substitution at the R3̅m metal (3a) site.
solution.effectiveness: Effective in enhancing cycle performance but resulted in a small reduction in capacity.

evidence.data: Cycle performance improved by ∼13% with Cr doping, as shown in electrochemical testing results.

context.material_properties: High capacity of ∼270 mAh·g−1 with layered structure (R3̅m space group).
context.experimental_conditions: Cycling tests performed at various rates (0.1C, 0.2C, etc.) and voltage windows (2.0–4.8 V).
context.application_relevance: Improved cycle performance is critical for extending battery life in energy storage applications.

challenge.description: Voltage decay during cycling, thought to originate from a transformation to a spinel-like phase at 3V.
challenge.impact: Voltage decay reduces the energy density and efficiency of the battery over time.

solution.methodology: Cationic substitution at the R3̅m metal (3a) site.
solution.effectiveness: Effective in reducing voltage decay, particularly during discharge, but did not enhance capacity.

evidence.data: Voltage decay suppressed by Cr doping, as shown in in operando neutron powder diffraction data.

context.material_properties: Layered structure with R3̅m space group symmetry.
context.experimental_conditions: Cycling tests performed up to 200 cycles under various charge/discharge rates.
context.application_relevance: Voltage stability is essential for maintaining consistent energy output in battery applications.

challenge.description: Poor cycle performance of F-doped material, retaining only ∼70% capacity after 200 cycles.
challenge.impact: Limits the long-term usability of the material in practical battery applications.

solution.description: F doping enhanced capacity and rate performance but worsened cycle stability.
solution.methodology: Anionic substitution at the R3̅m oxygen (6c) site.
solution.effectiveness: Improved initial capacity and rate performance but led to structural instability during cycling.

evidence.data: Capacity retention of ∼70% after 200 cycles, compared to ∼90% for Cr-doped material.

context.material_properties: Layered structure with increased lattice parameter due to F doping.
context.experimental_conditions: Cycling tests performed under asymmetric charge-discharge profiles (0.2C/0.5D).
context.application_relevance: Structural stability is critical for maintaining performance in long-term battery use.

challenge.description: Difficulty in determining the crystallographic position of low-level dopants (F and Cr).
challenge.impact: Complicates the understanding of the relationship between doping and electrochemical performance.

solution.description: Used neutron powder diffraction (NPD) combined with Rietveld refinement to model dopant positions.
solution.methodology: High-resolution NPD data and structural modeling techniques.
solution.effectiveness: Provided insights into dopant positions but could not rule out the presence of minute amounts of dopants in secondary phases.

evidence.data: NPD data revealed Cr at the 3a site and F at the 6c site within the R3̅m phase.

context.material_properties: Layered structure with mixed transition-metal occupancy.
context.experimental_conditions: Neutron diffraction performed at OPAL reactor using ECHIDNA instrument.
context.application_relevance: Accurate structural characterization is essential for optimizing doping strategies to improve battery performance.
